metadata.case_name: Petitioners v. State of Maharashtra & Ors.

facts.text: Three petitioners filed petitions under Art. 32 challenging promotions by first respondent (State of Maharashtra) of respondents 2 to 5 and others to officiating Executive Engineers, ignoring petitioners' claims, contrary to natural justice and violating Arts. 14 and 16.
All three petitioners were directly recruited by Public Service Commission as Deputy Engineers in Bombay Service of Engineers Class II (now Maharashtra Service of Engineers Class II).

First petitioner appointed on 9th June 1959, confirmed 9th June 1961; second on 11th June 1959, confirmed 24th June 1961; third on 12th June 1959, confirmed 18th June 1961. Confirmation relates back to appointment date for seniority.

Respondent No. 2 from erstwhile State of Bombay; respondents 3 and 4 from former State of Hyderabad; respondent No. 5 from former State of Madhya Pradesh; others similarly allocated to Bombay/Maharashtra under States Reorganisation.

Respondents 2 to 34 were in substantive rank of overseers, only officiating as Deputy Engineers, required 7 years actual service after confirmation as Deputy Engineers for promotion to officiating Executive Engineers.
State promoted respondents 2-34 as officiating Executive Engineers before completing 7 years actual service after confirmation.
By resolution dated 23rd February 1967, respondents 3,4,6-14 (ex-Hyderabad) treated as appointed temporary Deputy Engineers w.e.f. 31st March 1957 for seniority and promotion.
Bombay/Maharashtra Service of Engineers consists of Class I and Class II (Deputy Engineers). Recruitment partly direct, partly promotion.
Rules framed under Government resolutions: 22nd March 1937; further rules 1939 for recruitment.
Resolution 21st November 1941: Seniority of direct recruits from probation date; promotees from substantive promotion date.
Gurjar Committee recommendations 1951 led to resolution 29th April 1960 on recruitment to Class I and II.
1960 Resolution: Ratio direct:promotion 75:25; probation 2 years for direct; confirmation after 9 years for Assistant Engineers unless extended.
Deputy Engineers Class II: direct recruits, confirmed from subordinate services, temporary DE by PSC, officiating DE.
Resolution 29th July 1963 amended 1941 rules: Seniority direct from probation; promotees from continuous officiating date, temporary or permanent.
Promotion principle: seniority-cum-merit per resolution 18th December 1950.

Resolution 4th March 1957: Committee of 3 Chief Engineers prepares annual select list of DE fit for Executive Engineers, requiring 7 years service in DE grade (excluding training, including probation).
Resolution 20th August 1965: Lists of overseers fit for DE promotion; service requirements: graduates 3 yrs, diploma 8 yrs, Osmania 10 yrs, non-qualified 13 yrs.
Channels: Executive Engineers from direct Assistant Engineers or DE Class II; DE Class II 75% direct, 25% promotees from subordinate service.
Ex-Hyderabad respondents selected by Hyderabad PSC in June 1956 as Assistant Engineers, would have appointed but for reorganisation 1-11-1956.
Ex-Hyderabad respondents allotted as overseers substantively post 1-11-1956, promoted officiating DE 1958-1963, not confirmed by promotion date.
Some respondents appointed officiating DE before 1-11-1956, confirmed after petitioners' appointment.
Some ex-MP/Hyderabad not gazetted SDO, treated DE from 1-11-1956 or not confirmed by promotion.
Select lists prepared for 1964 and 1965; petitioners not included due to lack of 7 years service and ACRs.
Petitioners' 7 years completed June 1965 (from 1959), entitled for 1966 consideration, but no list made for 1966 mentioned.

legal_issues.text: Whether respondents required 7 years actual service after confirmation as Deputy Engineers for promotion to officiating Executive Engineers, or whether continuous officiating service suffices.
Whether treating ex-Hyderabad respondents as temporary Deputy Engineers w.e.f. 31-3-1957 for seniority/promotion was arbitrary and violative of Arts. 14, 16.
Whether petitioners entitled to be considered for promotion via select list under 1957 rules, and if omission violates Arts. 14, 16.
Binding nature of government resolutions (1960, 1963 etc.) as executive instructions vs. rules under Art. 309.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondents were only officiating DE, not in cadre; require 7 years after confirmation as DE for promotion; direct recruits like petitioners senior from appointment date.
Ex-Hyderabad respondents allotted as overseers, not selected by Bombay PSC; arbitrary deeming as temporary DE from 31-3-1957.
Promotion only after confirmation and 7 years service; officiating DE not in Class II until confirmed.

respondent_arguments.text: 7 years qualifying service is continuous officiating as DE, not from confirmation; rules do not require substantive/permanent service.
Promotion based on select list (1957); petitioners not included due to service length/ACRs; no right to promotion if not selected.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: seniority-cum-merit; State of Mysore v. Syed Mahmood

respondent_arguments.text: Ex-Hyderabad selected pre-reorganisation; equitable to treat as temporary DE from 31-3-1957 under States Reorganisation Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: States Reorganisation Act; Allocated Govt. Service Rules 1957

respondent_arguments.text: Resolutions are executive instructions, not statutory rules; Govt. entitled to issue.

court_reasoning.text: 1960 Rules do not require 7 years permanent service; continuous officiating/temporary service counts; 1963 clarifies seniority from continuous officiating.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No indication in rr.6,7,8 that qualifying service must be post-confirmation; temporary/officiating counts for absorption.

court_reasoning.text: Class II includes promotees from officiating list after 3 years officiating; eligible for promotion after 7 years total service in grade.
court_reasoning.key_observation: r.7(ii) requires from Class II service, not 'belong' post-confirmation.

court_reasoning.text: Ex-Hyderabad selected pre-reorg; Govt. entitled to deem appointment 31-3-1957 for seniority under Reorg Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Recognises just claims; no statutory bar.

court_reasoning.text: Promotion on seniority-cum-merit via select list; petitioners not in 1964/65 lists due to service/ACRs; no mandamus if considered but unfit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cites State of Mysore v. Syed Mahmood: no right by seniority alone if unfit.

court_reasoning.text: Resolutions are executive instructions without statutory force, but 1960 rules interpretation supports respondents anyway.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not made under Art. 309; no formalities followed.

holdings.text: 7 years service for promotion includes continuous officiating/temporary as DE, not only post-confirmation.
Deeming ex-Hyderabad appointments from 31-3-1957 valid; not arbitrary.
No violation of Arts. 14,16 as promotions per seniority-cum-merit select list; petitioners not eligible/not selected.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Mysore v. Syed Mahmood
precedents_cited.relevance: Promotion on seniority-cum-merit; no right if unfit, even if senior.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitions under 32 for enforcement of 14,16; rules not under 309.

statutes_cited.name: States Reorganisation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Allocation of service, equation of posts, seniority for ex-Hyderabad/MP/Bombay employees.

outcome.summary: Court rejected petitioners' contentions, upheld promotions as per rules and select lists, no violation of Arts. 14 or 16; petitions dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "Only such officers should be selected for inclusion in the select list as have put in at least seven years service (excluding the period of training but including the period of probation) in the grade of Deputy Engineer."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Where the promotion is based on seniority-cum-merit the officer cannot claim promotion as a matter of right by virtue of his seniority alone."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From cited precedent; crux of no mandamus for petitioners.

key_quotes.text: "The seniority of promotees should be considered as from the date of promotion to officiate continuously irrespective of whether the appointments are made in temporary or in permanent vacancies."
key_quotes.speaker: court
